thread.title_full: What the Stoics can teach a Lions (or Bears) fan - Chicago Tribune

author: Scott Samuelson
title: What the Stoics can teach a Lions (or Bears) fan - Chicago Tribune
text:
Last Sunday, in our upper-level seats at Ford Field, as the Arizona Cardinals ran up the score against the Detroit Lions, I introduced my 13-year-old son, in his vintage Barry Sanders jersey, to the ancient philosophical school of Stoicism.
With the Lions heading for 0-5 and droves of fans heading for the exits, I explained to Billy that Stoicism, a philosophy conceived in ancient Greece and popular in ancient Rome, has always been relevant to the human condition — especially the human condition of football fans in Detroit.
Chicago has its Stoics, too, of course. Until recently they were called Cubs fans, although now they have passed the title over to fans of the Chicago Bears, who play the Lions on Sunday in what could be a Stoicism faceoff.
According to the Stoics, we have happiness backward. We think we'll be happy if things go our way. Because they don't often go our way, we're usually miserable.
As the first-century Stoic Epictetus tells us: "Don't demand events to happen as you wish; but wish them to happen as they do, and you will be happy."
"You mean we should want the Lions to lose their fifth straight?" Billy asked, as only a teenager can.
The great Stoic metaphor, I explained, is that we're like dogs leashed to a powerful chariot. When the chariot moves, we have two choices: trot or be dragged. Either way, we end up in the same place. "What's the point in being dragged?" I asked.

(Dan Wiederer) Billy is a historian of the game. He reminded me that the Lions' all-time record in the Super Bowl is 0 for 0, that they haven't won a single playoff game in his lifetime and that they've won just one playoff game in my lifetime. He detailed the infamous bad call against Calvin Johnson, the botched interference call that cost us a win in the playoffs last year and the missed call that lost us the recent game against Seattle. He also brought up the sore point that when he was 6 years old, and his father was brainwashing him to love the Lions, they went 0-16 and were, it is widely agreed, the worst team in league history. "Is this what happiness looks like?" he asked.
Stoicism, I calmly retorted, is often misunderstood as a loser's philosophy. It's not that we shouldn't bother seeking out victory. We should strive to do the best at whatever activity we find ourselves in, including being a Lions fan. But we should accept that winning and losing are ultimately outside our control. I explained to my son that we should practice the two lessons parents always preach to their children about playing sports: "Try your best" and "It's only a game."
"Isn't that like Barry Sanders' attitude?" the budding philosopher suddenly interjected, pointing proudly at the No. 20 on his jersey. "Even though he was on the Lions, he never got down about how much they sucked. He just did his job and was the greatest running back of all time."
As the Lions on the field below continued their pursuit of an early first-round draft pick, Billy and I talked of how we should live our lives like Barry Sanders played football. Always striving for our best, we should neither be upset when we lose nor gloat when we win.
"Dad, are you telling me all this because you think I'm not enjoying the game?"
"I guess."
"Are you crazy?" he said. "We just saw Calvin Johnson break the Lions' franchise record for career catches. Sure, I wish the Lions would win, but I'm having a great time. Maybe your little Stoic lecture has been more for you than me?"
At this point Dan Orlovsky, the backup quarterback remembered by Detroit fans as the guy who once ran blithely out of the back of our end zone for a safety, threw an interception. Sitting on the other side of Billy, my father, in his blue and silver pullover, shook his head and chuckled ruefully. His worldview is closer to the ancient philosophical school called Cynicism.
Scott Samuelson, a lifelong Lions fan, is the author of "The Deepest Human Life: An Introduction to Philosophy for Everyone" (University of Chicago Press, 2014).
